article_title: Hospitals penalized for excess readmissions of some patients
article_text:
Hospitals penalized for excess readmissions of some patients

Photo: KIN MAN HUI, STAFF / SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS-NEWS Baptist Health System is seeing the most significant cut locally,...

Some San Antonio hospitals are being penalized with cuts to their Medicare reimbursements for what the federal government says are excessive readmissions of patients within a month of release.

article_metadata.description: Some San Antonio hospitals are being penalized with cuts to their Medicare reimbursements for what the federal government says are excessive readmissions of patients within a month of release.  The performance program, established by the Affordable Care Act, reduces Medicare payments to hospitals found to have excessive readmissions of Medicare patients originally hospitalized for heart attacks, heart failure, pneumonia, chronic lung problems and elective hip or knee replacements.  “Readmissions are often expensive, adverse events for patients and are a marker of the quality of care that a hospital provides,” said a Hospital Inpatient Quality Reporting Program fact sheet posted on CMS’ QualityNet  website, a storehouse of health care performance data.  To help avoid readmissions, the hospital has a registered nurse who follows up with patients after their release to make sure they keep their doctor appointments and take their medications.  The hospital said its readmission rate for knee or hip replacement patients surpassed the national average for two quarters during the evaluation period, but this has since been corrected and is now well below national levels.  The readmission measures “help us focus on opportunities to improve patient care and how that care is documented, particularly with respect to preparing patients prior to surgery and efforts to manage their post-hospitalization course,” said Peterson Regional Medical Center CEO Patrick Murray in a prepared statement.  Patient compliance with hospital discharge instructions, including follow-up visits to their primary care physician or specialist and taking prescribed medications, are factors which could cause a readmission back into the hospital.  Local hospitals never penalized include Christus Santa Rosa Health System, Foundation Surgical Hospital of San Antonio, Methodist Ambulatory Surgery Hospital, South Texas Spine and Surgical Hospital, and Victory Medical Center’s San Antonio facilities.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
